subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Re: Thoughts on My Antique Communication Device?
author: Zack Widup
full_text:
I have one somewhat similar to it. I was going to remark that the cat
whisker assembly seems to be missing.

Those things were designed to be used with a set of high-impedance
headphones.

Zack


On Tue, Oct 26, 2010 at 2:14 PM, vortex6066 <vortex6066@...> wrote:

>
>
> Its a crystal radio receiver. Probably made in the early 20's judging by
> the condition and parts used. The front controls are tuning and headphone
> volume.
> A crystal detector is meant to plug into that socket, and the set wont work
> without it. A (modern) germanium diode could be used instead and soldered
> across the socket terminals.
> The wire on the coil looks like its loosing its insulation so the coil is
> probably faulty and would have to be re-wound.
> JEFF
>
>
> --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com <EVP-ITC%40yahoogroups.com>, Kris Bronson
> <the_rocker_chick1@...> wrote:
> >
> > I'll be the first to admit I'm no expert when it comes to ITC. The
> majority of
> > my experience comes from working with Chris (Moon) and his box for the
> past 3
> > years. The results still never cease to amaze me!
> >
> > Anyhow, I came across this device at an estate auction. It appears to be
> an
> > antique communication device of some sort. The only verifiable
> information I
> > have is that is was probably built around 1910-1912, which is before
> radio was
> > publicly available.
> > (I obtained this date from researching the packaging cylinder used to
> build the
> > device.)
> >
> > Does anyone have any thoughts on what it might be? I did show this device
> to
> > Chris a while back and he agreed that it probably was a communication
> device. He
> > also suggested I show it to Frank... = )
> > According to Chris's box, "this IS a communication device of historical
> value."
> > It also mentioned the device was "meant specifically for me to have, but
> no
> > longer worked." There was more, but I'm trying to remain unbiased and
> only
> > use tangible evidence. However, I have little to go on.
> >
> > If anyone has any clues or can lead me in a research direction I would
> > appreciate it! Thanks!
> >
>
>  
>

I ha e one somewha simila o i . I was going o ema k ha he ca whiske assembly seems o be missing.Those hings we e designed o be used wi h a se o high-impedance headphones.Zack
